facts.text: This case is Civil Appeal No. 992 of 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 992 of 1973. Appeal from the judgment and order dated the June 4, 1973 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore in Writ Petition No. 774 of 1973. N. Byra Reddy, A. K. Sen, M. Veerappa, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated June 4, 1973 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore in Writ Petition No. 774 of 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the June 4, 1973 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore in Writ Petition No. 774 of 1973. N. Byra Reddy, A. K. Sen, M. Veerappa, for the appellant. S. Javali and B. R. Agarwala, for the respondent.

facts.text: Shri Bidap, the respondent, was appointed Member of the State Public Service Commission by the Governor of Mysore on March 20, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: One Shri Bidap, the respondent in this appeal, was appointed Member of the State Public Service Commission by the Governor of Mysore on March 20,, 1967. While his term was still running, the Governor was pleased to appoint him Chairman of the Commission with effect from February 15, 1969.

facts.text: Governor appointed Shri Bidap Chairman of the Commission with effect from February 15, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: While his term was still running, the Governor was pleased to appoint him Chairman of the Commission with effect from February 15, 1969. The State took the view that the six years assured to him by Article 316 2  companymenced to run from the date he became Member simpliciter and did number receive a fresh start from the later date when he assumed office as Chairman.

facts.text: State took the view that the six years term commenced from March 20, 1967 and ended on March 19, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The State took the view that the six years assured to him by Article 316 2  companymenced to run from the date he became Member simpliciter and did number receive a fresh start from the later date when he assumed office as Chairman. Governments view on the issue was revealed in answer to an interpellation in the Legislative Council made on March 17, 1973.

facts.text: Government's view revealed in answer to interpellation in Legislative Council on March 17, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Governments view on the issue was revealed in answer to an interpellation in the Legislative Council made on March 17, 1973. On this-reckoning the Chairmans term would have ended on the 19th and so, the panicked respondent hastened to the High Court to avert the peril of premature ouster and sought an appropriate writ interdicting Governments move.

facts.text: Respondent filed Writ Petition No. 774 of 1973 in Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On this-reckoning the Chairmans term would have ended on the 19th and so, the panicked respondent hastened to the High Court to avert the peril of premature ouster and sought an appropriate writ interdicting Governments move. The timely interim order and the eventual allowance of the writ petition balked the hope of Government and drove the State to this Court in quest of a final pronouncement on the companystitutional question involved.

facts.text: Mysore High Court allowed the writ petition on June 4, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The timely interim order and the eventual allowance of the writ petition balked the hope of Government and drove the State to this Court in quest of a final pronouncement on the companystitutional question involved. While there is divergence of judicial opinion at the High Court level, the preponderance of authority, including a ruling of the Mysore High Court itself, militates against the appellants stand- point.

facts.text: State appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The timely interim order and the eventual allowance of the writ petition balked the hope of Government and drove the State to this Court in quest of a final pronouncement on the companystitutional question involved.

facts.text: There is divergence of judicial opinion at High Court level, preponderance against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: While there is divergence of judicial opinion at the High Court level, the preponderance of authority, including a ruling of the Mysore High Court itself, militates against the appellants stand- point. A broad companysensus of administrative practice evolved by the Union Government in response to an opinion tendered by the Attorney General on a reference made to him at the instance of the Conference of All India Chairmen of Public Service Commissions  prompted by divergent views expressed in a full Bench judgment of the Calcutta High, Court  also goes against the appellants position.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Full Bench judgment in AIR 1966 Cal. 290.

anchor.surface_text: Conference of All India Chairmen of Public Service Commissions  prompted by divergent views expressed in a full Bench judgment of the Calcutta High, Court  also goes against the appellants position. Technically, neither the appellant number, for that matter, any citizen is bound by administrative verdicts on questions of law and when the High Courts disagree, the law becomes uncertain necessitating resolution of the companyflict by the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Mysore High Court ruling in Writ Petitions Nos. 6492, 5031 and 3758 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore High Court was companyfronted with this question in Writ petitions Nos. 6492, 5031 and 3758 of 1969. There the challenge to the validity of the Chairmans companytinuance in office was made by certain disappointed applicants for the post of District Educational officer.

facts.text: Orissa High Court decision reported in AIR 1970 Orissa 205.

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa High Court also fell in line with Mysore, dissenting from the majority judgment in the Calcutta case. That decision, reported in AIR 1970 Orissa 205, reads into the appointment of a Member as Chairman an ipso facto cessation of his former office as Member when he enters upon the duties of his new office,

facts.text: Patna High Court judgment in C.W.J.C. 1997 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Patna responded to this issue in a like manner in a judgment rendered in C.W.J.C. 1997 of 1970  reproduced at pages 54 to 61. of vol. II of the paper-book . It may be numbericed that a special leave Petition against this judgment was dismissed in line by- the Supreme Court  the said order is Ext. C in the writ petition .

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed special leave petition against Patna High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: It may be numbericed that a special leave Petition against this judgment was dismissed in line by- the Supreme Court  the said order is Ext. C in the writ petition . It number remains to understand the ratio of those decisions in the light of the anatomy of the companystitutional scheme companytained in Arts. 316 to 319.

facts.text: In twelve states and the Union, only two instances beyond eight years of tenure and 19 cases more than six years, as per Ext. G.

anchor.surface_text: In this companytext, it is reassuring to numbere that in twelve states and the Union there have been, as disclosed by Ext. G, only two instances beyond eight years of tenure and only 19 cases where more than a six year term is seen to have been obtained.

facts.text: Administrative practice over last over two decades reads Art. 319(d) as enabling fresh term from date of appointment as Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: May be Ext. G is number exhaustive, and incidentally it indicates the practice which has prevailed in the companyntry during the last over two decades of reading Art. 319 d  as, enabling a fresh term of office from the date of appointment as Chairman.

facts.text: Union Government evolved administrative practice in response to Attorney General opinion on reference from Conference of All India Chairmen of Public Service Commissions.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we dismiss the appeal with companyts.

facts.text: Mysore High Court followed minority view of Mitter, J. in Calcutta case in its own ruling.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court followed the minority view of Mitter, J. and the respondent in this appeal has produced a companyy of the Mysore Judgment as Ext. B along with his Writ Petition since the ruling has number been reported.

Writ Petition No. 774 of 1973. N. Byra Reddy, A. K. Sen, M. Veerappa, for the appellant. S. Javali and B. R. Agarwala, for the respondent. N. Sinha, Solicitor General of India and S. P. Nayar, for Intervener No. 1.

The State took the view that the six years assured to him by Article 316 2  companymenced to run from the date he became Member simpliciter and did number receive a fresh start from the later date when he assumed office as Chairman. Governments view on the issue was revealed in answer to an interpellation in the Legislative Council made on March 17, 1973. On this-reckoning the Chairmans term would have ended on the 19th and so, the panicked respondent hastened to the High Court to avert the peril of premature ouster and sought an appropriate writ interdicting Governments move. The timely interim order and the eventual allowance of the writ petition balked the hope of Government and drove the State to this Court in quest of a final pronouncement on the companystitutional question involved. While there is divergence of judicial opinion at the High Court level, the preponderance of authority, including a ruling of the Mysore High Court itself, militates against the appellants stand- point. A broad companysensus of administrative practice evolved by the Union Government in response to an opinion tendered by the Attorney General on a reference made to him at the instance of the Conference of All India Chairmen of Public Service Commissions  prompted by divergent views expressed in a full Bench judgment of the Calcutta High, Court  also goes against the appellants position. Technically, neither the appellant number, for that matter, any citizen is bound by administrative verdicts on questions of law and when the High Courts disagree, the law becomes uncertain necessitating resolution of the companyflict by the Supreme Court. It is apt to remember the words of Rich, J- One of the tasks of this Court is to preserve uniformity of determination. It may, be that in performing the task the Court does number achieve the uniformity that was desirable and what uniformity is achieved may be uniformity of error. However in that event it is at least uniformity.  1  Moreover, in a Government of laws like ours, the last companyrt has the last word on a given law, it being permissible to the Legislature, subject to companystitutional limitations, to amend the law, if necessary. The question in the present case being one of general public importance has to be decided by this Court silencing the present and potential disputes and laying down a binding rule for the whole companyntry. Counsel for the appellant strenuously companytends that there is high policy animating the provisions, which limit the official life of a Member of the Public Service Commission to a significantly short term of six years companypled with an almost blanket ban on the holding Waghorn v. Waghorn, 65 Commw. L. R. 239, 293  1942 . of other office or taking up of other employment under Government on ceasing to be a Member. Before, we focus on the fasciculus of Articles 316 to 319 to assess the force of this and other submissions, two basic questions fall to be companysidered. Is there any public policy of great moment behind these Articles and if so, what is it ? Secondly, assuming its existence and importance, companyld this Court, while interpreting the provisions of the Constitution, listen to such extrinsic voices, however natural logical and persuasive or be guided by the olden rule of grammatical companystruction which treats the text of the statute as a sort of forensic sound-proof room ? The working life, of an Indian official in administration can easily be, and is, several times the six short years granted to a Public Service Commission Member under Art. 316 2 . Further employment in public service is also number unusual for superannuated officers, particularly at the higher echelons. And yet there is substantial, although number total, prohibition of subsequent employment in public service of Commission Members written into the Constitution by Art. 319. The learned companynsel rightly stresses that the Public Service Commission has vast powers of recruitment of candidates for an immense and increasing host of Government posts which in a companyntry with companysiderable unemployment are prom to be abused if too close and too long a familiarity with certain sectors were to be established. The prospect and peril of the Executive, tempting with renewals of membership to influence the incumbents may companyrupt that institution, which must zealously be kept above suspicion. This is the reason detre of the narrow period prescribed by Art. 316 2 , the taboo on reappointment in Art. 316 3  and on taking up of any Government service clamped down by Art.

concepts.interpretation: A member holds office for six years from the date he enters upon his office; Chairman and Member are different offices, so elevation to Chairman starts a fresh six-year term; no reappointment to the same office.

concepts.unlisted_description: Appointment and terms of office of Members of Public Service Commission

anchor.surface_text: At this stage we may read Arts. 316, 317 and 319 in extenso 316  1  Appointment and terms of office of Members. The Chairman and other Members of a Public Service Commission shall be appointed in the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission by the President, and in the case of a State Commission, by the Governor of the State Provided that as nearly as may be one half of the members of every Public Service Commission shall be persons who at the dates of their respective appointments have held office for at least ten years either under the Government of India or under the Government of State, and in companyputing the said period of ten years any period before the companymencement of this Constitution during which a person has held office under the Crown in India or under the Government of an Indian State shall be included.  1A  If the office of the Chairman of the Commission becomes vacant or if any, such Chairman is by reason of absence or for any other reason unable to perform the duties of his office, those duties shall, until some person appointed under clause  1  to the vacant office has entered on the duties thereof or, as the case may be, until the chairman has resumed his duties, be performed by such one of the other members of the Commission as the President, in the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission, and the Governor of the State in the case of a State Commission, may appoint for the purpose. A member of a Public Service Commission shall bold office for a term of six years from the date on which he enters upon his office or until he attains, in the case of the Union Commission, the age of sixty-five years, and in the case of a State Commission or a Joint Commission, the age of sixty years, whichever is earlier Provided that-  a  a member of a Public Service Commission may, by writing under his hand addressed, in the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission, to the President, and in the case of a State Commission, to the Governor of the State, resign his office  b  a member of a Public Service Commission, may be removed from his office in the manner provided in clause  1  or clause  3  of Article 317.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for removal and suspension of Members only on specific grounds like misbehaviour after SC inquiry under Art.145.

concepts.unlisted_description: Removal and suspension of Members of Public Service Commission

anchor.surface_text: Prohibition as to the holding of office by members of Commission on ceasing to be such members. On ceasing to hold office-  a  the Chairman of the Union Public Service Commission shall be ineligible, for further employment either under the Government of India or under the Government of a State  b  the Chairman of a State Public Service Commission shall be eligible for appointment as, the Chairman or any other member of the Union Public Service Commission or as the Chairman of any other State Public Service Commission, but number for any other employment either under the Government of India or under the Government of a State  c  a member other than the Chairman of the Union Public Service Commission shall be eligible for appointment as the Chairman of the Union Public, Service Commission or as the Chairman of a State public Service Commission, but number, for any other employment either under the Government of India or under the Government of a State  d  a member other than the Chairman of a State Public Service Commission shall be, eligible for appointment as the Chairman or any other member of the Union Public Service Commission or as the Chairman of that or any other State Public Service Commission, but number for any other employment either under the Government of India or under the Government of a State.

holdings.text: The six-year term under Article 316(2) is reckoned from the date on which the member enters upon the specific office held, so a Member elevated to Chairman mid-term gets a fresh six-year term from the date of entering the Chairman's office.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-Art.  2  sanctions the holding of office by, a member for six years from the date on which he enters upon his office which is signified by his entering on the duties thereof, to adopt the language of  1A . An office, as is thus self-evident, has duties and a member simpliciter has certain duties while a Chairman has other duties of. office.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of Articles 316(2), 316(3), and 319(1)(d); offices of Member and Chairman are distinct with different duties; term starts from entering specific office; consistent with prior High Court views (Mysore, Orissa, Patna).

holdings.text: The office of ordinary Member is distinct from the office of Chairman, despite both being 'members' under Article 316.

anchor.surface_text: A Chairman is also a member, as the very first words of Art. 316 indicate. Nevertheless, the office of member is different from that of Chairman and so also the duties attached to each, as is eloquently evident from Art. 316 1A .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction in Articles 316(1A), 317, 319; different duties; elevation not reappointment to same office.

holdings.text: Article 316(3) prohibits reappointment only to the identical specific office previously held, not to a distinct office like elevation from Member to Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: Article 316 3  neatly fits in and indeed the draftsman has perspicaciously focussed attention here on the office of a person  as distinct from membership  and the incumbents ineligibility to reappointment to that office.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Focus on 'that office' meaning specific office; prefix 're-' implies same office; reconciles with Article 319(1)(d).

holdings.text: Article 319(1)(d) permits a member of a State PSC, on ceasing to hold office as member, to be eligible for appointment as Chairman of that same Commission, implying a fresh appointment.

anchor.surface_text: But this apparent tenor gets a severe jolt when we turn to Art. 319 1   d , for, if full credit were to be given to the opening words, on ceasing to hold office a member of a Public Service Commission is declared to be eligible for appointment as its Chairman

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain text allows eligibility post-cessation; applies to normal term expiry, not only Art.317(3) cases; reductio ad absurdum otherwise; mid-term elevation implies ipso facto cessation of Member office.

holdings.text: There is a public policy behind Articles 316-319 to ensure independence of Public Service Commissions by limiting tenure, barring reappointment, and restricting post-tenure employment to prevent executive influence and abuse.

anchor.surface_text: Before, we focus on the fasciculus of Articles 316 to 319 to assess the force of this and other submissions, two basic questions fall to be companysidered. Is there any public policy of great moment behind these Articles and if so, what is it ? Secondly, assuming its existence and importance,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Short tenure, no reappointment, employment bans to obviate abuse; supported by Constituent Assembly debates and historical context (Lee Commission); but does not override textual interpretation.

holdings.text: In cases of obscurity or ambiguity in constitutional provisions, courts may refer to extrinsic aids like legislative history with caution, whittling down the strict exclusionary rule.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, assuming its existence and importance, companyld this Court, while interpreting the provisions of the Constitution, listen to such extrinsic voices, however natural logical and persuasive or be guided by the olden rule of grammatical companystruction which treats the text of the statute as a sort of forensic sound-proof room ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Critique of exclusionary rule; logical relevance in ambiguity; cites Frankfurter, Stone; but not decisive here as text clear.

holdings.text: Appointment of a Member as Chairman mid-term implies ipso facto cessation of the ordinary Member office upon entering Chairman duties.

anchor.surface_text: The obvious answer is that when a member holding the office of a member takes up the office of Chairman, he, by necessary implication and companyinstante, relinquishes or ceases to hold his office as ordinary member.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary implication to avoid holding two offices; reconciles Articles 316 and 319; reduces membership count otherwise.

precedents.citation: Waghorn v. Waghorn, 65 Commw. L. R. 239, 293  1942

anchor.surface_text: It is apt to remember the words of Rich, J- One of the tasks of this Court is to preserve uniformity of determination. It may, be that in performing the task the Court does number achieve the uniformity that was desirable and what uniformity is achieved may be uniformity of error. However in that event it is at least uniformity.  1  Moreover, in a Government of laws like ours, the last companyrt has the last word on a given law, it being permissible to the Legislature, subject to companystitutional limitations, to amend the law, if necessary. The question in the present case being one of general public importance has to be decided by this Court silencing the present and potential disputes and laying down a binding rule for the whole companyntry.

precedents.cited_proposition: One of the tasks of this Court is to preserve uniformity of determination even if it is uniformity of error.

anchor.surface_text: Anglo-American jurisprudence, unlike other systems. has generally frowned upon the use of parliamentary debates and press discussions as throwing light upon the meaning of statutory provisions. Willes, J. in Miller v. Tayler, 1 , stated that the sense and meaning of an Act of Parliament must be companylected from what it says when passed into law, and number from the history of changes it underwent in the House where it took its rise.

precedents.cited_proposition: The sense and meaning of an Act of Parliament must be collected from what it says when passed into law, and not from the history of changes it underwent in the House.

precedents.citation: Assam Railways and Trading Co. Ltd. v. I.R.C., 2

anchor.surface_text: That history is number known to the other House or to the Sovereign. In Assam Railways and Trading Co. Ltd. v. I.R.C., 2  Lord Writ in the Privy Council said It is clear that the language of a Minister of the Crown in proposing in Parliament a measure which eventually becomes law is inadmissible and the report of companymissioners

precedents.case_name: Assam Railways and Trading Co. Ltd. v. I.R.C.
precedents.cited_proposition: Language of a Minister in proposing a measure and reports of commissioners are inadmissible as evidence of legislative intention.

precedents.citation: State of Travancore-Cochin and others v. Bombay Company Ltd., Alleppey, 1

anchor.surface_text: The rule of grammatical companystruction has been accepted in India before and after Independence. In the State of Travancore-Cochin and others v. Bombay Company Ltd., Alleppey, 1  Chief Justice Patanjali Sastri delivering the judgment of the Court, said - It remains only to point out that the use made by the learned Judges below of the speeches made by the members of the Constituent Assembly in the companyrse, of the debates on the draft Constitution is unwarranted.

precedents.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Bombay Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Use of speeches by members of the Constituent Assembly in debates on the draft Constitution is unwarranted for interpretation.

precedents.citation: Administrator General of Bengal v. Prem Lal Mullick, 22 nd. Appl. 107  P.C.  at p. 118.

anchor.surface_text: That this form of extrinsic aid to the interpretation of statutes is number admissible, has been generally accepted in England, and the same rule has been observed in the companystruction of Indian statutes See Administrator General of Bengal v. Prem Lal Mullick, 22 nd. Appl. 107  P.C.  at p. 118.

precedents.case_name: Administrator General of Bengal v. Prem Lal Mullick
precedents.cited_proposition: Rule excluding extrinsic aids like debates observed in construction of Indian statutes.

precedents.citation: Gopalan v. Slate of Madras,  1.950  S.C.R. 88

anchor.surface_text: The reason behind the rule was explained by, one of us in Gopalan v. Slate of Madras,  1.950  S.C.R. 88 thus A speech made in the companyrse of the debate on a bill companyld at best be indicative of the subjective intent of the speaker, but it companyld number reflect the inarticulate mental process lying behind the majority vote which carried the, bill.

precedents.cited_proposition: A speech in debate indicates only speaker's subjective intent, not the majority's mental process.

precedents.citation: United States v. Trans- Missouri Freight Association,  1897  169 U.S. 290 at p. 318

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it reasonable to assume that the minds of all those legislators were in accord. Or, is it is more tersely, put in an American case-United States v. Trans- Missouri Freight Association,  1897  169 U.S. 290 at p. 318  sic . This rule of exclusion has number always been adhered to in America,

precedents.case_name: United States v. Trans-Missouri Freight Association
precedents.cited_proposition: Those who did not speak may not have agreed with those who did, and speakers might differ.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is this question of law res integra. The Calcutta High Court had companysidered it in a Full Bench decision reported in AIR 1966 Cal. 290. The majority view was that the term of office of six years was to be companyputed from the date of the appointment as Member of the companymission and even if, in midstream he was made Chairman.

precedents.case_name: Calcutta High Court Full Bench decision
precedents.cited_proposition: Term of six years computed from appointment as Member, even if later made Chairman; majority view.
precedents.cited_holding: Term runs from member appointment, no fresh term as Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore High Court was companyfronted with this question in Writ petitions Nos. 6492, 5031 and 3758 of 1969. There the challenge to the validity of the Chairmans companytinuance in office was made by certain disappointed applicants for the post of District Educational officer.

precedents.cited_proposition: Followed minority view of Mitter J.; fresh term as Chairman.
precedents.cited_holding: Appointment as Chairman gives fresh six-year term.

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa High Court also fell in line with Mysore, dissenting from the majority judgment in the Calcutta case. That decision, reported in AIR 1970 Orissa 205, reads into the appointment of a Member as Chairman an ipso facto cessation of his former office as Member when he enters upon the duties of his new office,

precedents.cited_proposition: Appointment as Chairman causes cessation of member office, fresh term.
precedents.cited_holding: Ipso facto cessation of member office upon becoming Chairman, reconciling Arts. 316 and 319.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Patna responded to this issue in a like manner in a judgment rendered in C.W.J.C. 1997 of 1970  reproduced at pages 54 to 61. of vol. II of the paper-book . It may be numbericed that a special leave Petition against this judgment was dismissed in line by- the Supreme Court

precedents.cited_proposition: Appointment as Chairman gives fresh term; SLP against it dismissed by SC.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal against the High Court's allowance of the writ petition dismissed; respondent entitled to fresh six-year term as Chairman from date of appointment as such

anchor.surface_text: Sub-Art.  2  sanctions the holding of office by, a member for six years from the date on which he enters upon his office which is signified by his entering on the duties thereof, to adopt the language of  1A . An office, as is thus self-evident, has duties and a member simpliciter has certain duties while a Chairman has other duties of. office.

Sub-Art.  2  sanctions the holding of office by, a member for six years from the date on which he enters upon his office which is signified by his entering on the duties thereof, to adopt the language of  1A . An office, as is thus self-evident, has duties and a member simpliciter has certain duties while a Chairman has other duties of. office.

A Chairman is also a member, as the very first words of Art. 316 indicate. Nevertheless, the office of member is different from that of Chairman and so also the duties attached to each, as is eloquently evident from Art. 316 1A .

A Chairman is also a member, as the very first words of Art. 316 indicate. Nevertheless, the office of member is different from that of Chairman and so also the duties attached to each, as is eloquently evident from Art. 316 1A .

Article 316 3  neatly fits in and indeed the draftsman has perspicaciously focussed attention here on the office of a person  as distinct from membership  and the incumbents ineligibility to reappointment to that office.

Article 316 3  neatly fits in and indeed the draftsman has perspicaciously focussed attention here on the office of a person  as distinct from membership  and the incumbents ineligibility to reappointment to that office.

But this apparent tenor gets a severe jolt when we turn to Art. 319 1   d , for, if full credit were to be given to the opening words, on ceasing to hold office a member of a Public Service Commission is declared to be eligible for appointment as its Chairman
